question.text: Leaves needle-like or scale-like and often overlapping
Leaves not needle-like, scale-like or overlapping
Leaves in pairs, opposite each other on shoots
Leaves alternate on shoots
Leaves divided into separate leaflets (compund leaf)http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leaflet
Leaves with one blade, possibly indented into lobes, but not divided into leaflets
Leaves evergreen
Leaves deciduous
Fruits fleshy or juicy
Fruits dry
All leaves scale-like, usually pressed against the twig
All leaves needle-like, usually spread widely apart
Some leaves scale-like, others needle-like
Scale-leaves at least 30mm long, rigid and sharp-edged
Scale-leaves less than 30mm long, not rigid or sharp
Deciduous tree; foliage is wispy; pink or white flowers
Evergreen tree with cones; foliage is dense
Cone is egg-shaped with overlapping scales, eventually wide- spreading like petals of a flower; crushed foliage smells of pineapple.
Cone is egg-or ball-shaped, scales meet at edges and don’t overlap, scales don’t become wide-spreading; crushed foliage doesn’t smell of pineapple.
Cone is egg-shaped with more than 15 scales meeting edge to edge; bark is very thick, with visible fibres, and is rather soft or spongy.
Cone is ball-shaped, with fewer than 10 scales; bark is hard.
Needles are in two flat, parallel rows, at least on the short shoots growing off longer ones; fruit is scarlet and berry-like
All the needles are in clusters or are parted on either side of shoot, but not in flat rows; fruit is a woody cone.
Needles are all on their own at their position on the shoot.
Most needles grouped around the shoot, in pairs or bundles of 2 or more.
Cones stand upright on branches; needles are attached by a sucker-like base.
Cones hang downwards from branches; the base of the needles are not sucker-like.
Needles are single, quite stiff, round or 4-sided in cross section
Needles are single, flat, linear, not stiff.
Most needles are in bundles of 2–5.
Most needles are arranged around the shoot in clusters of 3, 10 or more, rarely in pairs.
Needles in bundles of 2
Needles in bundles of 3
Needles in bundles of 5
Needles on all shoots are arranged in rings of 3 going around the shoot, or occasionally in pairs
Needles on short shoots, in clusters of 10 or more
A deciduous tree; the cones are egg-shaped
An evergreen tree; the cones are barrel-shaped
Leaves of main shoots are scale-like, leaves of short shoots are needle-like, up to 20mm long, arranged in 2 rows; foliage doesn’t smell unpleasant
Leaves mostly scale-like; those towards the tips of shoots are needle-like, in opposite pairs, 5–6mm long; crushed foliage smells unpleasant
Leaves are divided palmately forming individual leaflets. Leaflets extend from the leaf petiole (stalk)
Leaves pinnately divided into separate leaflets, the leaflets in two rows on the stalk
Leaves are sometimes lobed, but are not divided into leaflets
A large bush or small tree. Bark is criss-crossed with corky ridges. The white flowers are in small clusters and,the fruit is a dark berry
Smooth or slightly wrinkled bark. Tall tree with dry, wing-shaped fruit
Tips of the branches are flattened where the leaves or buds are attached; leaves have soft hairs on underside; A single fruit on each stalk
Twigs are not flattened where the buds or leaves are attached; leaves are hairless on the underside; fruits in pairs on the stalks
No petals on flowers; winter buds black; leaf up to 35cm with 7-13 lanceolate, pointed leaflets (up to 12 cm), very hairy midrib
Narrow white petals on flowers; winter buds brown or grey; leafs up to 30 cm with 9 toothed, ovate leaflets (10cm long) veins underneath have brown or white hairs
Leaves have deep lobes; wing-shaped fruit hangs in pairs
Leaves not lobed / shallowly-lobed; fruit is woody capsule, berry or a long pod
Toothed leaf edges
Leaf edges untoothed
An evergreen tree that usually has green/bluish-green leaves that smell strongly of eucalyptus if crushed; bark often flaking or shredding
A deciduous tree with bright green or pale leaves, whcih do not smell when crushed; bark does not shred

A tall tree up to 20m; ovate leaves to 25cm long with heart-shaped base ; flowers 5cm long, white petals with purple and yellow spots; fruit is long, slender pod to 40cm that remains long after the leaves fall
A small tree to 8m; leaves are 4–10cm long; flowers are 4mm across; fruit is a red berry
Leaves with 3-13 lobes; If 5-lobed, any teeth present are large, pointed, and not numerous or flowers and fruits don’t hang in tails
Leaves up to 15cm with 5-lobes and numerous small, round-tipped, coarse, teeth; flowers and fruits hang in tails
Leaves composed of 3 leaflets
Leaves divided into 3 or more leaflets
Thick twigs, covered with velvety hairs; flower heads and seed heads are dense, hairy, and cone-shaped
Twigs not velvety; flowers and fruits not present in cone-shaped heads
Each leaf usually has a pair of 2mm thorns at the base, which can be 2cm on young shoots or absent on adult crown shoots
Twigs have no spines or thorns
Twigs have Y-shaped scars in places where leaves have fallen; 5-9 eliptical leaflets per leaf; yellow catkins or clusters of 1–5, female flowers greenish with yellow
Leaf scars are not Y-shaped; twigs that are cut do not seep latex; flowers are abudant in clusters
Leaflets not lobed and they are not foul-smelling; fruits are pods
Leaflets have some lobes or teeth confined to the lower half; leaflets are foul-smelling upon crushing; the fruit is a winged papery wing
Lobed or toothed leaflet that are not foul-smelling; fruit is a papery capsule
Leaflets are at least toothed in the upper half and not foul-smelling when crushed; fruit is berry-like and juicy
Up to 8 pairs of leaflet/leaf, which are toothed on the top half; Bark rich-brown with ridges and fissures; buds rounded, smooth, green.
5-8 pairs of leaflets/leaf that are markedly toothed round most of the margin; Bark silver/grey and quite smooth; oval buds, mostly purple with curved tips and grey hairs
Ripe fruits entirely orange-red to vermillion-red (occasionally yellow), with yellow pulp
Ripe fruits white to pink or crimson, with white pulp
Leaves have spiny edges
Leaves might have toothed margins, but they are not spiny
Leaves are green and glossy on top, paler and downy underneath; acorns as fruit; green flowers, the male flowers are in slender catkins
Leaves are pale underneath, which is hairless; red berry fruit; white flowers in small clusters
Leaves are aromatic when crushed
Leaves are not aromatic when crushed
Leaves smell strongly of eucalyptus if crushed, or less commonly of lemon; the leaf edges are flat
Leathery, shiny leaves up to 20cm long 6cm wide; Smooth margin with a a few very small teeth; Leaves smell of almond when crushed; black ripe fruits
Leathery, tough leaves that smell of bay when crushed; wavy margins
Underside of leaves covered densely with grey or rusty brown hairs
Hairless leaves or with white hairs on the underside
Flowers on their own; width of leaf equal to or greater than half the length
Flowers are in clusters; width of leaf less than half the length
Leaves to 11cm with prominent midrib and red petiole; Flowers white(sometimes tinged green or pink) roughly 1cm long, in pendulous clusters; fruit is red berry to 2cm with warty skin
Bell-shaped flowers 4–6cm long, bell-shaped pinkish-red in large rounded clusters; fruit is a dry capsule with many dry seeds
Flowers are in long spikes, each spike has up to 100 bell-shaped flowers 1–1.5cm across; fruit is a ovoid/round, smooth, shiny black berry with stone
Leaf entire margin, dark green above and white and hairy below; Flowers less than 1cm, flat and in clusters; fruit to 5mm, round and red
Leaves are fan-shaped with a central notch
leaves are not fan shaped
At least some leaves are lobed
Leaves are undivided, the edges may be toothed but not lobed
Leaves are palmately lobed, distinctly bristly to the touch on the upper side
Leaves are pinnately lobed, smooth or softly hairy on the upper side
Some leaves are lobed and all are toothed; the fruit resembles a raspberry, red or purple when ripe
All leaves are lobed; the fruit is pear-shaped and brownish purple when ripe
Twigs are thorny
Twigs are not thorny
Leaves are not toothed
Leaves are toothed
Flowers and fruits are in cylinder- or cone-shaped spikes
Flowers and fruits are on their own, in pairs or in clusters
Flowers are less than 10mm in diameter, the petals are broadly oval; the fruit is smooth at the apex
Flowers are more than 10mm in diameter, the petals are narrow and strap-shaped; the fruit is crowned with the withered sepals
Flowers have 1 style; sepals are absent on the ripe fruit; 1 seed
Flowers have 2 or more styles; sepals are usually present on the ripe fruit; 2 or more seeds
Twigs are very thorny
Twigs are not thorny or have only occasional thorns
Fruit is less than 2cm long; the bark often has distinctive horizontal bands of pores
Fruit is more than 2cm long; the bark doesn’t have horizontal bands of pores
Fruit has a velvety skin, even when fully ripe
Fruit has a smooth skin, often with a greyish waxy bloom on the skin
Young twigs are green, smooth and glossy
Young twigs are brown or grey, dull and often hairy
Flowers and fruits in clusters of 11 or more, with their stalks not arising from a central point
Flowers and fruits in clusters of 10 or fewer, with their stalks all arising from a central point
Twigs are thorny or spiny, sometimes with very few spines
Twigs are not thorny
Fruit is usually pear-shaped, with gritty flesh; styles are not joined together at the base
Fruit is usually apple-shaped, the flesh is not gritty; styles are joined together at the base
Fruits less than 4cm long
Fruits more than 4cm long
Leaves are lobed
Leaves are not lobed
Leaves are square or notched at the tip; the flowers are up to 5cm long and are on their own
Leaves are rounded or pointed at the tip; the flowers are much smaller, in clusters or catkins
Leaves are pinnately lobed; the fruit is an acorn
Leaves are palmately or irregularly lobed; the fruits form a catkin or globe-shaped head
Leaves are felted with white or grey hairs on the underside
Leaves are smooth or sparsely hairy on the underside
Bark is flaking in large patches; the fruits form a soft, hairy ball like a pom-pom
Bark is fissured, not flaking; the fruits form a stiff, spiky ball like the head of a mace
Bark is silver or white
Bark is greyish or brown
Tree is weeping, the twigs and smaller branches hang loosely; the bark has black, diamond-shaped splits
Tree is not weeping; the bark is often peeling but doesn’t have black diamond-shaped splits
Leaves are more than 3 times as long as they are wide
Leaves are less than 3 times as long as they are wide
Leaf edges are coarsely toothed, the teeth end in a softly spiny tip; the seeds are enclosed in a softly spiny husk
Leaf edges are not indented but may have small, fine teeth; the seeds have a plume of silky hairs at one end
Tree is weeping, the smaller branches hang downwards, often almost to the ground
Tree is not weeping
Fruit is a small, woody cone, they are numerous and stay on the tree until spring
Fruit is not a woody cone
Leaf edges aren’t indented
Leaf edges are toothed, the teeth may be very small
Leaf are double toothed
Leaves are almost circular; flowers are pea-like and found on the trunk and main branches as well as the twigs
Leaves are oval or egg-shaped; flowers aren’t pea-like
Leaves are flat and 15cm or more in length; the flowers have 5 or more large petals that are white or pink; the fruit is cone-like but not woody
Leaves are up to 9cm long with wavy edges; the flowers are greenish and don’t have petals; the fruit has a spiny husk
Flowers and fruits are in clusters suspended beneath an oblong, wing-shaped bract; the leaves are roughly heart-shaped
Flowers and fruits are in cylindrical catkins; the leaves are oval to oblong
Flowers are in small clusters; the fruit is a seed surrounded by a papery wing
Flowers are in slender, hanging catkins; the fruit is a nut
Leaves hairy on both surfaces; fruits are solitary or in clusters of a few; each nut is wrapped in a leafy sheath
Leaves hairy only on veins on the underside; fruits are in a hanging catkin, paired nuts are attached to a large, 3-lobed, bract
Flowers or fruits arranged in roughly cylinder-shaped spikes, 11 or more per spike
Flowers or fruits on their own or in clusters of 10 or fewer
Leaves hairless or with white hairs along midrib, sometimes only where veins join; flowers 10-15mm across
Leaves have rusty or orange hairs underneath, each side of the midrib; flowers 8mm across
Flower and leaf stalks densely hairy; leaf edges have pointed teeth
Flower and leaf stalks hairless or almost hairless; leaf edges have pointed teeth, often with thin, bristle-like tips
Flower and leaf stalks hairless; leaf edges have blunt or round teeth, often with a claw-shaped gland at the tip
Sepal edges are toothed; leaves hairless on the upper side with hairy veins on the underside
Sepal edges not toothed; leaves hairy on both surfaces
Bark on trunk and branches very glossy, purplish-brown and peeling in thin, copper-brown strips
Bark mostly dull grey or brown, sometimes peeling to reveal shiny red-brown on the trunk
Flowers less than 20mm across, on stalks up to 15mm long, not arising from a central point; fruit less than 10mm long
Flowers more than 20mm across, on stalks more than 15mm long, arising from a central point; fruit more than 10mm long
Flowers cup-shaped; leaves dull on the upper side, sparsely hairy on the underside
Flowers saucer-shaped; leaves glossy on the upper side, hairless on the underside

node.name: Bird cherries
node.latin_name: Bird cherry(Prunus padus), Virginian bird cherry(Prunus virginiana)

node.name: Rowan with white, pink or crimson fruit
Rowans with orange or vermillion fruit
Hemlock Spruces
node.description: A spruce is a tree of the genus Picea, a genus of about 35 species of coniferous evergreen trees in the Family Pinaceae, found in the northern temperate and boreal (taiga) regions of the earth. Spruces are large trees, from 20–60 metres (66–200 ft) tall when mature, and can be distinguished by their whorled branches and conical form.

node.name: Spruces
node.description: A spruce is a tree of the genus Picea, a genus of about 35 species of coniferous evergreen trees in the Family Pinaceae, found in the northern temperate and boreal (taiga) regions of the earth. Spruces are large trees, from 20–60 metres (66–200 ft) tall when mature, and can be distinguished by their whorled branches and conical form.

node.name: Firs
node.description: Fir(Abies) is a genus of 48–55 species of evergreen coniferous tree in the family Pinaceae. It is found through much of North and Central America, Europe, Asia, and North Africa, occurring in mountains over most of the range. Firs are most closely related to the genus Cedrus (cedar); Douglas-firs are not true firs, being of the genus Pseudotsuga.

node.name: Yew
node.description: Taxus baccata is a conifer native to western, central and southern Europe, northwest Africa, northern Iran and southwest Asia.[1] It is the tree originally known as yew, though with other related trees becoming known, it may be now known as the English yew, or European yew.

node.name: Cypresses (including false cypresses)
node.description: Evergreen. Shaped like cones or columns, with generally up-swept branches hiding much of the trunk.

node.name: Wellingtonia
node.description: Evergreen. Reaching 90m when full grown, with the trunk up to 7m in diameter. The crown is narrowly cone-shaped, with down-swept branches.

node.name: Western Red Cedar
node.description: It is a large to very large tree, ranging up to 65–70 metres (213–230 ft) tall and 3–4 metres (9.8–13 ft) in trunk diameter, exceptionally even larger. Trees growing in the open may have a crown that reaches the ground, whereas trees densely spaced together will only exhibit a crown at the top, where light can reach the leaves.[4] It is long-lived; some individuals can live well over a thousand years, with the oldest verified being 1,460 years.

node.name: Tamarisks
node.description: Slender and rather twiggy, often with several stems. They are deciduous.

node.name: Monkey Puzzle
node.description: Araucaria araucana (popularly called the monkey puzzle tree or monkey tail tree) is an evergreen tree growing to 40 metres (130 ft) tall with a 2 metres (7 ft) trunk diameter. The tree is native to central and southern Chile, western Argentina, and southern Brazil. Araucaria araucana is the hardiest species in the conifer genus Araucaria. Because of the species's great age it is sometimes described as a living fossil.

info.info_text: There are around 500 species of Oak in the northern hemisphere. The two most common in Britain are listed here. Follow the link to find information on other species

question.text: Shoots and buds are hairless. leaves deeply-lobed
Buds are brown-orange with white, long hairs. Acorns egg-shped, stalkless, sit directly on twig in small clusters

node.name: Pendunculate (English) oak
node.description: A large spreading tree with a dense grown of heavy branches

node.name: Sessile oak
node.description: A sturdy tree with a domed shape. The bark is grey-brown with vertical fissures
